This is, rather incredibly, Mr. Mukhopadhyay's first film, and it exhibits the passionate, more-is-more abandon of an artist bursting with welcome (if exhausting) enthusiasm onto the scene.
Dark Streets has atmosphere coming out its ears, but not much going on between them.
With Sleepwalking Land, the filmmaker Teresa Prata creates an affecting portrait of life during wartime.
Directed by Steve Carr, a man who knows how to put a camera in front of things, if little else, and written, sort of, by Nick Bakay and Mr. James.

If only a glimpse, the privilege compensates: one wants more from Ballerina because the world it reveals -- elegant and harsh, glamorous and grinding, classical and obsolete -- proves so rich in exquisite contradictions.
Between Love & Goodbye tells of the ill-fated romance between a pair of East Village transplants with 2 percent body fat, zero personality and even less chemistry.
The Color of Magic mashes together a pair of comedic fantasy novels by Terry Pratchett into one long, rambling saga.
This sort of thing was indulgent enough the first time around; transplanted to the mumblecore milieu, it's intolerable.
An indecisive mix of tepid camp and gory gross-out, "The Gay Bed & Breakfast of Terror" doesn't go far enough in either direction.
movie_title: The Gay Bed and Breakfast of Terror (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The strongest material in An Unlikely Weapon contemplates the import of that shot, and of photojournalism itself, on the events of its time.
In Empty Nest, a couple is forced to question their identities and relationships now that parenting is not their most immediate concern.
The movie is, as these things go, enjoyably trashy.

Raw, rueful, and piercingly alert, a film of tremendous formal instinct and cogent human truth, J'entends is an oblique memoir of the filmmaker's relationship to Nico (Steege) -- and a testament to the elusive genius of a postwar French master.
movie_title: I Can No Longer Hear the Guitar (J'entends Plus La Guitare) (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Directed with rigorous tact, L'Amour fou is unconcerned with speaking through any historical framework. It is devoted, rather, to the calm, thoughtful, and ultimately elusive reflections of M. Bergé on the dismantling of a legacy.

Pootie Tang works, in part, because it doesn't. Which is to say the movie's special success is inextricable from the moments where it blatantly fails. The movie exerts a beguiling charm that can only be explained as the je ne sais quoi of sa da tay.
She Hate Me isn't subversive, it's insipid.
It is devoted, rather, to the calm, thoughtful, and ultimately elusive reflections of M. Bergé on the dismantling of a legacy
Her latest, Anatomy of Hell, doesn't so much straddle the fine line between art and porn as balance, bleeding, on the knife's edge between trenchant and pretentious.
A slog through lazy writing, indifferent acting and blase direction with no hope of anything but chaotic violence as reward.

Keep the Lights On acknowledges (without belaboring) the performative nature of identity; how each of our claims to selfhood, be it sexual, romantic, or professional, are staged on a shifting terrain of habit, fantasy, and desire.
Scanners consolidates the ruling problematic of the Cronenberg project from the sex slugs of Shivers to the financial abstractions of Cosmopolis: what are the effects of signals on an organism?
A "map to the stars" can be two different things: a tacky accessory of celebrity culture, or a diagram of cosmic energy.
A clockwork noir of diabolical determinism.
Complications pile up, confrontations are manufactured, and numerous Mexican baddies materialize as the runtime needlessly heads past the two-hour mark.
The September Issue is a misshapen, mix-and-match affair, an ill-fitting ensemble of individually compelling pieces.

The Assignment is not so naïve as to presume that "moral and political considerations" are irrelevant to its effect, but once you wrap your head around the premise the effect is more or less played out.
Produced by indie stalwart Larry Fessenden, the sophomore feature from writer-director Ilya Chaiken stages an uncommonly acute, deftly played drama of the New York working class.
A movie that continually puzzles over what it is and why it is being made.
Perestroika is a curious combination of documentary and fiction, politics and science, sophisticated structure and incompetent drama.

Matthew Barney's humongous riff on struggle, reproduction, conceptual drag, and several dozen strands of narrative gobbledygook is undeniably something to be reckoned with--if only as a relic of the boom years in contemporary art.
This sharp, gutsy indie is one of the year's great discoveries.
The filmmaker Graham Reznick arrives with a bang in his feature debut, the experimental horror film I Can See You.

Just as burlesque loses most of its oomph when put on video -- no art is more dependent on the intimacy of live performance -- self-esteem trips are less compelling to hear about than to experience firsthand.
The film's hesitation, lack of rhetorical inflation and commitment to humble observation generate a tough poetry. Ice People sticks in the mind.
With a script that snaps and characters that pop, Next Day Air nears neo-blaxploitation perfection.
Audience of One follows the descent of a scrappy indie production into a full-blown fiasco and megalomaniacal folly.
Even the least of Mr. Jacobs's efforts illuminate a rare imagination.
The most impressive special effect here is Mr. Matsumoto's hilariously restrained performance, a tour de force of comedic concision in a movie bloated by increasingly surreal developments.
An elegant but unsatisfying drama of cross-cultural lesbian love triangles.
An unrelentingly tedious documentary.
Kassim Ouma has, to say the least, an unusual life story....The filmmaker Kief Davidson recounts this vivid tale in the dull documentary.
The Vogels [Herb and Dorothy], sitting in their same old apartment, overflowing as ever, make for charming company.
There are any number of reasons a group of filmmakers would choose so idyllic a locale to mount a production. Making an interesting movie, however, does not appear to have been one of them.

Directed by Paul Devlin, this absorbing documentary flirts with metaphysics...but mostly it keeps an amused eye on the effort of these driven brainiacs to set aloft an extremely sophisticated and fragile recording device.
The director, Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi, is in thrall to her subject, and dewy-eyed accounts of pop stars, even those with as compelling a biography as Mr. N'Dour, tend to wear out their welcome.
movie_title: Youssou Ndour: I Bring What I Love (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For all its limitations, Nollywood Babylon serves as an intriguing primer.
Unstructured and free-associative, cutting among interviews and images at breakneck speed to no discernible narrative or thematic purpose, the documentary is mercurial to the point of incoherence.
Stephane Gauger's debut feature, Owl and the Sparrow, is a charming little movie, nothing more.
Keith Haring was not a great artist. He might not even have been a very good one. But he was the right person in the right place at the right time.
If nothing else, Mr. Guerin has neatly captured the sweet, erotic alienation of being a single man at his leisure in a foreign town, dazzled by the passing procession of local beauties.
movie_title: En la Ciudad de Sylvia (In the City of Sylvia) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, unnerving, and sharp as an icicle to the eye, Transsiberian is the chilliest of midsummer thrillers.
Wry, good-natured picture.
A Jihad for Love is a dispatch from the outer limits of marginalization: a documentary on devout Muslims struggling with their homosexuality.
An intrepid, unlikely and altogether splendid feat of D.I.Y. reportage.
Infantile, irreverent and boorish to the max, Postal explodes with bad attitude and lousy filmmaking.
This sleeper hit in the making is sweet and sour in all the right proportions, the best thing of its kind since Napoleon Dynamite.

A compendium of six short films by French filmmakers, any one of which might prove diverting in the right place at the right time but all of which, cumulatively, donâ(TM)t much make for a knockout night at the cinema.
movie_title: "L'Origine de la tendresse" and Other Tales (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Directed by Erik Nelson, Dreams With Sharp Teeth recalls the career of Harlan Ellison, a runty young geek who evolved into a world-famous artist.
That Paraguayan Hammock happens to be one of the few features to emerge from Paraguay in recent decades in no way diminishes its rarity.

Anyone can send an immense, computer-generated vegetable monster rampaging at the base of the Brooklyn Bridge, but it takes a special kind of imagination to do it in a way that's thrilling, emotionally complex, and rapturously beautiful all at once.
Max Kohn (Otto Tausig), the aging Lothario of Love Comes Lately, is very much like the movie itself: doddering and milquetoasty, but ultimately disarming.
I take no pleasure in dumping on a 25-year-old pseudo-experimental nature documentary, but neither did I find much to like in Blue Planet.
So earnest it hurts, Kicking It follows a half-dozen homeless men from around the globe as they ready for the fourth annual Homeless World Cup in Cape Town.
This uncommonly elegant and evocative portrait of Louise Bourgeois reveals much about the haunting and haunted master while leaving intact the thing you cannot explain.
movie_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine (2008)

movie_review_blurb: All in This Tea is a delicious documentary about a beverage.
An eye-popper and brain-boggler, Razzle Dazzle is also, remarkably, a thing to stir the soul.
You've seen this sort of thing before, but the film, directed by Paul Taylor, happens to be especially well photographed, and the youngsters more winning than most.
movie_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The season's freshest, most sympathetic movie about making your way in modern-day Manhattan with a little help from your friends.
La Rivière Gentille affords an exceedingly long afternoon in the company of the artist Louise Bourgeois.
Shot piecemeal over the course of four years on locations in 18 countries, The Fall is a genuine labor of love -- and a real bore.
Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead is just about as perfect as a film predicated on the joys of projectile vomiting and explosive diarrhea can be.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The mechanism is the message in Cloverfield, a movie so aluminum-sleek, ultra-portable, and itsy-bitsy sexy, it's amazing Steve Jobs didn't pull it out of an envelope at Macworld.

Untraceable hasn't the brains of a class-act psychothriller like Silence of the Lambs, and lacks the balls to juice up the trashy verve of the Saw series. Stuck in the middle, it leaves everyone stranded, actors and audience alike.

Immy Humes no doubt needed to make this movie, and the PR set (Mailer, Matthiessen, Plimpton) obviously enjoy the trip down memory lane, but while Doc makes for a fascinating subject, Doc feels intended less for us than for them.
Téchiné's triumph of compassion and craft shames the American cinema's indifference to gay history.
Crass, shrill, disingenuous, tawdry, mean-spirited, vulgar, idiotic, boring, slapdash.
The debut feature of writer-director Paul Andrew Williams is a grim, efficient affair.
The devil's in the details, and Diary is diabolically resourceful within its circumscribed framework.
Dilemma is an earnest if schematic attempt to address conditions in Johannesburg under apartheid.
I leave you to discover, through covered eyes, the gut-splattering delirium to come.
An impeccably constructed illustration in depth, ceaselessly alert and cumulatively profound.
More than a mash note to this nonpareil maestro, Apparition circles around the mystery of music and subjectivity and touches down on a head-spinning array of topics.

As signaled by the transparent naming of his characters, Bahrani inflects his drama with documentary, grabbing sights and sounds directly from the street in a dexterous update of neorealist strategies.
Green keeps mum until the end, charging his tale with an effective (if manipulative) aura of suspense.
All told, and well told, this is essential history.
Unpersuasive as drama, Tears is the first and last Wong movie touched by any feel of the obligatory.

A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, Hollywood Chinese surveys a centuryâ(TM)s worth of Chinese-American actors and filmmakers, visionaries and dragon ladies, kung fu excellence and Fu Manchu insult, Oscar winners and clichÃ (C) mongers.
The Duchess of Langeais contemplates an especially crazy case of l'amour fou.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Harold is the type of one-note dead zone ideally suited for a bathroom break while sitting home on a Saturday night, alone and semidrunk, in front of the television.
...Silly, awkward, vulgar, outlandish, hysterical, inventive, revolting, flamboyant, titillating, ridiculous, mischievous, uproarious, cheap, priceless, tasteless and sublime.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with The Reflecting Pool, an investigative drama that mucks around with 9/11 conspiracy theories, is not that its ideas are silly.
There's a deeper, touching acknowledgment of braggadocio as persona, how the commodified dissent of hip-hop lends itself to masking insecurities.
Directed by the Pang brothers (Danny and Oxide), Bangkok Dangerous is a halfhearted remake of their 1999 picture of the same name.
If it sounds like the cutest thing in the history of cuteness, that's because it is.
Joins show-time antics to sociocultural commentary without reducing its characters, colorful as they are, to cartoons.
If the movie follows no single thread of inquiry, nor sustains any argument or research in depth, it nevertheless explores some chilling corridors of the clandestine.
Unavoidably, an insidery affair. But even those who have never talked mise-en-scene...will be intrigued by this affectionate look at a legendary cinephile and prime mover of the movies.
A Thousand Years of Good Prayers is a gentle, pleasantly unrushed piece of moviemaking.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Never quite shaking off its aura of second-rate made-for-TV movie, this gay conversion melodrama has a lot of heart but little nerve and no surprise.
This powerful, conceptually sure film is relevant beyond the concerns of the moment as both a model of documentary method and compassionate social filmmaking.
A tender, fascinating documentary by Matt Wolf, will delight the cult and instantly convert new members.
movie_title: Wild Combination: A Portrait of Arthur Russell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Beverly Hills Chihuahua approaches but never quite achieves a truly spectacular level of absurdity.
Cheap shots and mean spirits abound, as do celebrity cameos. But it's the laziness of the writing that most offends.
Night and Weekends simultaneously plays like a critique of the mumblecore ethos and an especially obnoxious example of its whimsical tics and insouciant solipsism.
Does the world need yet another peppy gay self-esteem indie like Tru Loved? Probably not, though the writer and director Stewart Wade pulls this one off with heart.
There is in fact an elephant in The Elephant King, but his keepers are far from royal.

Despite a stiffness of movement that suggests an upscale take on the cutout animation of South Park, the movie has a terrific flair for arabesque patterning, a gemlike luminosity of surface and a handsome, classical cast of mind.
movie_title: Azur et Asmar (Azur and Asmar: The Princes' Quest) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like most flower-power nostalgia trips, Eight Miles High has the irksome effect of reminding the audience " whether too young or too square " that it missed out on the grooviest moment in history, man. But as these things go, this one goes with
Disaster Movie, the latest disposable parody of disposable Hollywood movies, has a shelf life of about five minutes, tops.
The Man From London, directed by Bela Tarr, is an outrageously stylized, conceptually demanding film.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Puts a cheerful spin on its many cliches. This particular wheel hasn't been reinvented, but at least it gets a nice fresh coat of bubblegum-pink paint and a star to pilot it with aplomb.
If there is anything the cinema needed less than another angst-ridden, cross-cutting tragedy about crime, fate, memory and redemption, it's the kind shot in an ugly monochromatic palette like Take.
It's no small feat to pull off as sweet and sensitive a romance as that between Na and Ton, and something rarer yet to suffuse such affections into a poem of wounded landscape.
A mockumentary about the people who run Manhattan nightlife, has solid-gold satire at its cocaine-stained fingertips.

Happily, the filmmaker, Jeremy Gosch, puts his wide-eyed narrative together with an easy touch. With its amazing wall-to-wall footage of oceanic derring-do Bustin' Down the Door plays like visual air-conditioning.
[Director] Leesong fails to extrapolate the insights of the brothel milieu into his larger agenda: a melodramatic love-hate affair between Sumin and Jaemin so schematic it's unintelligible.
Stealing America: Vote by Vote might have been this year's most alarming and patriotic documentary if it weren't so shoddy and dull.
Though [Director] Mr. Rose can't be blamed for waxing nostalgic, he can't much expect us to care about so fawning and self-serving a document.
This wretched gaysploitation number is, in fact, the worst gay sequel ever.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While Poston bears witness to a historical disgrace, it also resonates with more current conflicts.
Star Wars: The Clone Wars comes as something of a surprise: it isn't the most painful movie of the year!
Fly Me to the Moon bills itself as the first animated feature created expressly for 3-D. Too bad it wasn't created expressly for, you know, pleasure or art.
Let's go ahead and get this out of the way because I'm sure you're dying to know: no, you shouldn't see Blitzkrieg: Escape From Stalag 69.
Directed by Thomas G. Miller, One Bad Cat brings fresh light to the artist Albert Wagner.
movie_title: One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What makes this one different? Absolutely nothing. (Sure, it's based on a true story, but I mean come on, whatever.)

No fancy talk here, just solid, monosyllabic obscenities; no flights of digital fancy, just souped-up monster cars flipping end over end in a napalm blaze and crashing in a crunch of flaming metal ouch.
The really oppressive thing here is the filmmaking itself.

Mr. Mehta's picture is a documentary, and while it ought to be included on every future copy of the Water DVD, his free-form portrait of real widows has more than enough visual beauty, graceful compassion and understated anger to stand on its own.
Gleason is an incredible documentary.
The film has some wonderful moments that will leave the audience laughing at times, and squirming in discomfort in others.
Wind River is a thrilling and deep meditation on life. Jeremy Renner gives a career best performance.
An intensely personal film, a triumph for Kumail Nanjiani, and one of the most hilarious and personal films this year.
Nothing this great has ever come from something so bad. A career-best performance from James Franco.
Edgar Wright returns with an incredible heist movie, built with love, precision and a great deal of fun. His best film yet, and surely one of the best films of the year.
This is an incredibly important story and a film that needs to be seen.
What results is one of the most bonkers, insane films I have seen.
It's nearly a perfect comic book film.
Though visually enticing, Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is bogged down by a bloated script and poorly written characters.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Plotless, joyless and cash-grabbing, The Emoji Movie deserves the brunt of our wrath because it showcases everything wrong with Hollywood.
Megan Freels Johnston is rather promising as a director, providing a visual for the film as delightful as your usual truck's treats.
Cut Shoot Kill is a mostly well-made indie horror, with a solid cast and direction, even though restraint would provide us with a tighter example of filmmaking on a budget.
Surprisingly, and unlike a pair of the titular heroes y-fronts, Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie never really rubs you up the wrong way.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We have the Academy to thank for bringing this warmly humorous Swedish gem to our attention - it's one of the year's most likeable films.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hampstead offers nothing new in its tired-out genre, serving up uninspired writing and bland direction against a British backdrop.
It's a real tug of war between what does and doesn't work and, unfortunately, My Cousin Rachel doesn't win.
Diary of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul is one of the worst films of the year so far and I don't think it will have much competition.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: People is an utterly fascinating watch.
The Most Hated Woman in America appears chained to the path of mediocrity, as is now typical with Netflix's original films.
movie_title: The Most Hated Woman In America (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite two talented leads, The House suffers from a script that doesn't utilize their talents, ultimately becoming forgettable as a result.
There is more to like in Something Like Summer than dislike but it doesn't make it easy: it feels sincere, but its issue with plot and characters drag it down considerably.
My Life As A Courgette isn't a kid's film - it's a family film, fit for viewing together and evoking discussion, reflection and consideration.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There is nothing new on display in In The Shadow Of Iris, and what it does offer plunges into something so disappointing that you can only consider it an unfortunate misfire.
Whether the world needs another male spy-cum-agent is another question altogether, but American Assassin is entertaining enough for this franchise to live another day.

It's vividly and powerfully illustrated, with Weiwei's striking aesthetic sensibilities pouring through but it fails to conjure the method of storytelling that would pay the topic the attention it deserves.
Clocking in at just 71 minutes, The Party packs in more laughs, satire and poignancy than most films could dream, turning its tragicomedy into a roaring success.
Because of some impressive performances, solid direction and bold decisions, it's difficult not to have fun with Netflix's latest creation.

American Made is as middle-of-the-road as they come; if the weather is particular depressing and you genuinely have nothing better to do - we've all been there - think about giving American Made a go.

Emotionally exhausting, The Family I Had is a powerful documentary. It is devastatingly sad but with a rare glimmer of hope - moving forward may be difficult but if anyone can inspire hope in the face of difficulty, it's Charity Lee.
No matter your final decision on the heart-stopping, nerve-shredding, gut-clenching The Killing of a Sacred Deer, one thing is for sure - you won't forget it in a hurry.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Victoria & Abdul is a warming and twee example of film-making for a very particular demographic, but it is definitely one of the better examples of its genre.
Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool is an insightful and touching love story.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The direction is fine but the script and pacing is creaky to say the least, ultimately abandoning Jungle up the creek without a paddle.
It's both delicate and confrontational, exploring the family unit, reactions to grief and identity with no-holds-barred access...Kingdom of Us is essential viewing
It is a phenomenal technical accomplishment, elevated to dazzling heights by a stunning cast, gorgeous score and touching story that unleashes the artist inside us all.
With a terrific concept at hand, if slightly undone by a weaker screenplay, Hell House LLC is definitely a decent watch in the run-up to Halloween.
Kingsman: The Golden Circle is unfocused, unrestrained and lacking a control that prevents it (finale aside) from reaching the heights of its predecessor - but it is just about fun enough.
Insulting audiences with College and Disaster Movie on the same weekend threatens to split the lucrative, undiscriminating dumb-ass demographic.

Without its mesmerizing lead performance, Traitor easily could have devolved into direct-to-DVD fodder. Instead, Cheadle illustrates how great acting can elevate standard-issue material into something much more haunting and ambiguous.

Though the filmmaking is playful at times, the film is essentially 90 percent message, 10 percent movie. Then again, sometimes a message is important enough to make other considerations seem irrelevant.
Funny excuses an awful lot, and at its best, Hamlet 2 is nothing short of hilarious.
There's nothing about the film's workmanlike, achingly conventional direction that says 'Fred Durst.' Thank God
Under the direction of co-writer Joshua Michael Stern, it emerges as third-rate Capracorn, leaden and lumpy where it should be swift and pointed.

Dragon Emperor doesn't exactly beg for a sequel (neither did The Mummy Returns, for that matter), but it'd be fun to watch the filmmakers try to outdo this dizzy spectacle in the arena of sheer ridiculousness.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Why resurrect one of the most beloved pop-culture phenomena of the Clinton era, after six years on the sidelines? The hopelessly tardy new X-Files sequel I Want To Believe never provides a compelling answer to that question.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: August is a brooding, boring indie drama about the death of the culture-wide hallucination that was the dot-com bubble, and the moment when countless dot-com millionaires on paper became real-life paupers.
Hellboy 2 breezes along on the strength of Perlman's brawling charisma, a likeable tone, and a deft combination of goofball humor, pathos, and big action setpieces.
Trumbo emerges as a son's bittersweet valentine to his old man, and a tribute to the senior Trumbo's resilience, wit, and outrage in the face of a national disgrace.
It's amusing but facile, reasonably clever but hopelessly glib.
Pop-culture riffing, winking double entendres, scatological humor, and silly names aren't just the foremost weapons in Myers' comic arsenal, they're all he's got.
There are scattered moments of craft throughout, but the gulf between his lofty aspirations and feeble accomplishments has seldom been wider or more chuckle-inducing.
There's something appealingly modest about The Promotion. It's a sweet, human movie.
It's never close to good, and it can't even get bad right.
If silliness equaled greatness, You Don't Mess With The Zohan would instantly join Citizen Kane and It's A Wonderful Life high atop the pantheon of great American films.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Low-energy and grindingly mediocre, it adds a whole new dimension to Harlin's wildly uneven oeuvre: tedium.
Tony Montana and Mark Brian Smith's acidic, vitriolic takedown of Duffy boasts the abrasive intensity of a migraine headache and the depth and scope of a bona fide American tragedy.

[Director] Bean writes interesting scripts that toy with big ideas, but the films that result aren't always good. (Or even bearable.) Here he sets out to make an aural Fight Club, but instead he's made a movie about a guy who really needs to buy earplugs.
In costume and character, Prendergast is a little funny and more than a little sad. So is the film.

Grim but ultimately hopeful, Flow makes a convincing, impassioned case that concerned citizens need to fight for the right to clean water just as assiduously as Yauch and his Beastie compatriots once demanded the right to party.
Quarantine feels awfully familiar, and it grows less convincing with each passing moment. At its worst, it abandons realism entirely and flirts with gory kitsch.

Eagle Eye should boast all sorts of contemporary resonance. But it'd probably feel just a little bit timelier and more relevant if it took place in a universe that bore even the faintest resemblance to our own.
As a babe-delivery system, The Spirit is a rousing success. In every other sense, it's a pronounced failure.
Even when it flies off the rails deep into its third act, Resurrected remains strangely hypnotic.
Nobel Son sadistically resurrects the Tarantino knockoff -- an unloved, foul-mouthed little bastard of a subgenre that should now go away forever.
Frost/Nixon finds an intriguing new angle on one of history's most documented and fascinating figures.
The Dukes could use more music and less sap, but it's refreshing to see a film about the problems of working-class men on the far side of middle age, struggling just to get by.
In Role Models, Wain buys into the sturdy commercial formulas he's spent his career mocking, but the results are so winning that they threaten to give selling out a good name.
Soul Men casts the best possible leads in the worst possible movie.
Conventional but absorbing.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The driving force is inertia and commercial calculation, not inspiration.
Pretty but overwrought, Hounddog doesn't deserve its infamy, nor does it merit being seen or remembered.
Pride And Glory would have felt second-hand and overly familiar even if it were greenlit in 1937 as a vehicle for Humphrey Bogart and Edward G. Robinson.
Martin Lawrence's long, sad devolution from the poor man's young Eddie Murphy to the poor man's late-period Eddie Murphy continues.
The Lord may work in mysterious ways, but the filmmakers behind sensitive, life-affirming indie dramas about brooding young men stumbling towards redemption are an awfully predictable lot.
Happened deviates greatly from Linson's winning little book in its particulars, but retains its sustained melancholy mood of low-key existential dread and dyspeptic wit.
A film destined for an undistinguished second life as a pay-cable plugger for decades to come, Sex Drive benefits from the low standards of the teen sex-comedy genre.

Unsubtle but gripping, Battle For Haditha illustrates how a military that treats every man, woman, and child as a potential enemy can soon find that such thinking constitutes a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Ember is seldom riveting, but it's consistently compelling, and its uncompromising literal and metaphorical darkness renders its climax enormously satisfying.
How To Lose Friends And Alienate People's title proves prophetic, only this time the people being alienated are the suckers in the paying audience.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like its lead characters, Lucky is wounded, lost, and impractical, but it has a messy, winning humanity and an agreeably leisurely pace that almost redeems it.
This isn't a movie: it's a feature-length Ralph Lauren commercial.
Perhaps in future exposes Roberts will uncover that ice is cold and furnaces hot.
Iron Man is the rare comic-book movie that makes the prospect of a sequel seem like a promise instead of a threat.
Run Fatboy Run isn't particularly hilarious or moving, but it's got just enough humor and pathos to render its myriad flaws almost forgivable. Almost.
Devoid of suspense and a major disappointment from a once-promising director...
Were the filmmakers really so wedded to every scene they couldn't find 15 minutes to cut? Besides, shouldn't we as a culture being moving on to depleting the comic potential of '90s nostalgia by now?
Christmas won't wow anyone with its audacity or originality, but it's bound to make plenty of people happy with its slick, crowd-pleasing familiarity.
Schmaltzy and borderline insufferable.
Infomercials are seldom this leisurely paced or austere.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A hopelessly stilted political drama that plays like U.S. News & World Report: The Movie.
Does Bee survive the hype? Not quite, but it is semi-charming and reasonably clever in that facile Dreamworks Animation kind of way.
A commercially savvy though ultimately empty combination of warped morality tale, mystery, gore-fest, and torture porn.
Legendary '70s heroin kingpin Leroy "Nicky" Barnes is filmed like a deposed king in exile in Mr. Untouchable, Marc Levin's slick look at one of New York's most notorious criminal masterminds.
It's a relentlessly downbeat, well-acted melodrama that's easy to admire, but intentionally impossible to enjoy.
Well-acted.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Stiffly written, didactic, and whiplash-inducing in its tonal shifts.
Reggaeton has officially come of age: The burgeoning subgenre now has a terrible, opportunistic exploitation movie to call its own.
The film will probably end up preaching to the converted, albeit in an engaging and surprisingly light-hearted fashion.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In an accomplished directorial debut, Gilroy gives the film a shadowy, autumnal hue and combines image and sound in sometimes surprising and ingenious ways.
It labors under the delusion that it's this year's revelatory, eye-opening Maria Full Of Grace, when it's little more than a B-movie with an overwrought conscience.
It seems destined to find an indulgent second home as an unusually classy slot-plugger over at Lifetime.
Apted's unexpected crowd-pleaser is inspirational, but also surprisingly entertaining.
Its absurdist scenarios serve as little more than a ramshackle frame for bizarre non sequiturs, stoned pop-culture riffing, and some of the weirdest gags ever to make it into a studio-released film.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Auteuil and Boon's appealing performances keep the film engaging throughout, but it's easy to pine for a dark, challenging film with this premise, pitched more toward a harrowing emotional reckoning than this film's ambiguous but inevitable happy ending.

[The film] bears many of the hallmarks of teen comedies, but also boasts virtues not generally associated with the genre, such as wit, class consciousness, multidimensional characters, and a penetrating intelligence.
Sensual but profoundly silly, Silk is ultimately little more than softcore porn with arthouse trappings, a moony, dopily romantic Red Shoe Diaries variation for the NPR set.
Secrets could easily lose 20 minutes, especially once it runs out of energy toward the end. But it's fun, goofy, and fleet enough to merit a third go-round.

The anxieties and angst of middle-class, middle-aged women remain rich, underexplored cinematic territory, but Hunt's instantly forgettable film does little to make this deep vein of cultural experience seem vital or exciting.
Nichols succeeds in spinning an entertaining yarn.
At its delirious worst, it's as pungent a Parisian cheese shop, offering a cornucopia of laughable scenes.
May takes its sweet time getting to the big day, but that eventually works in its favor, since the filmmakers are ultimately more concerned with the journey than the destination.
The 'Aren't these geezers adorable?' approach ends up diminishing his subjects rather than honoring them.
The Visitor is a low-key, naturalistic, beautifully observed character study about the quiet angst of the buttoned-down soul.
The film's weakest moments are also its timeliest.
Despite its potential to be a turkey for the ages, Singer's blandly proficient historical thriller is fatally forgettable.
Michael Radford's leisurely paced Flawless digs itself into a deep, cavernous hole in its opening scene and never manages to crawl out of it.
It might even be bad enough to inspire Catcher author J.D. Salinger to break his decades of public silence to speak out against this high-camp fiasco.

As in her superlative debut feature Boys Don't Cry, [director] Peirce explores politically incendiary subject matter with empathy, sensitivity, and a particularly sharp sense of place, in this case, a lovingly depicted Texas.

It's Tyler Perry's aesthetic in a nutshell: strong, suffering female protagonists, no-good men, clear-cut ethical quandaries, schizophrenic tonal shifts handled as gracefully as bumper-car collisions, and a complete absence of moral ambiguity.
Well-intentioned to a fault, Sleepwalking blurs the line between dramatizing free-floating misery and spreading it.

City Of Men has its share of problems, but being too entertaining isn't one of them. The film isn't bad by any means, but after God's adrenaline-shots-to-the-heart rush, the laid-back storytelling comes off as a little sleepy.

Ferrell still brings the funny like few superstars in his salary range, but there's a distinct decline in quality between the hilarious Anchorman, the sloppy but funny Blades Of Glory, and this affable, moderately amusing trifle.
This time out, [Romero's] heavy-handed intellectual concerns get in the way of a perfectly good fright flick.
Stumbl[es] gracelessly from point A to point B and hitting all the expected notes in the process.
West is heavy on Vaughn, at least initially, but woefully short on comedy.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fool's Gold is a disposable beach paperback of a movie, easy to digest and even easier to forget.
At its best, Caramel boasts a quietly engaging slice-of-slice casualness.
Stiffly written, woodenly acted, and indifferently directed.
Well-meaning but fairly dull.
Anyone who's seen any recent movie about troubled youngsters expressing themselves through dance-offs has essentially already seen this.
First Sunday pits the street against the church, but somehow affable mediocrity wins the day.

As long as money retains the power to poison men's souls, Anderson's uncompromising masterpiece will continue to resonate as a harrowing cautionary warning to a country with oil pumping through its veins, clouding its judgment and coarsening its soul.
Vampires Suck finds Friedberg-Seltzer evolving ever so slightly, but adequacy remains out of their grasp, and mediocrity might just be an impossible goal.
Even pandering fairy tales about the innate decency of common people should have at least a fuzzy basis in reality.
If nothing else, Last Chance Harvey proves that you're never too old to be the subject of a zany trying-on-dresses montage, but considering the prestige of its leads, that's a minor victory at best.
Amy Adams is a sentient ball of cuteness, but not even she nor her appealing co-star Matthew Goode can keep this gimmicky contraption afloat.
Betty Thomas delivers pretty much the bare minimum: peppy, brightly colored, tune-filled nonsense sure to meet the low, low standards of its pre-kindergarten core audience.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Crazy Heart could use more rough edges, but while it's a little too sentimental and tidy, Bridges' humane, deeply empathetic lead performance makes it easy to root for one man's redemption.
A Single Man proves a film can look and feel like a 99-minute perfume commercial and still register as a poignant meditation on grief, memory, and loss.
Even more than the remake that it is, Everybody's Fine plays like a homogenized, Hallmark Channel version of About Schmidt, with all the rough edges shaved off.
If Ninja Assassin boasted sexual content equivalent to its level of violence, it would be rated NC-17 and repulse even the most dedicated perverts
A terminally bland coming-of-age story about a pretty young man with the worldâ(TM)s most awesome after-school job.

Ten9Eight will induce shivers of excitement in free-market proponents who get off on watching ambitious, money-minded young people pull themselves up by their bootstraps and set out to become future titans of industry.
The End Of Poverty? offers simplistic answers to many of the most pressing questions of our time.

Youth In Revolt is a little too clever and a little too willfully verbose for its own good, but it's rare and a little wonderful to see a comedy about the sex lives of teenagers that suffers from an excess of ideas and ambition instead of a dearth.

The bond between Brocheré and Borval is more physical than verbal; they often seem on the verge of a deep, soulful lip-lock, but since neither character is developed satisfactorily, it's hard to develop a rooting interest in...their friendship.
movie_title: Le Chant des Mariées (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sanders delights in the amateurishness of blaxploitation, from clunky exposition to shootouts that violate all rules of continuity and perspective to a visible boom mic, which spends so much time onscreen that it practically deserves its own credit.
At best, Paranormal Activity makes the banal and commonplace deeply unsettling.

An Education shares with Hornby's best work trenchant insight into the way smart, hyper-verbal young people let the music, films, books, and art they love define themselves as they figure out who they are and what they want to be.
In chronicling the permutations of black hair, the filmmaker ends up making a breezy statement on the universality of narcissism.
Given the duo's withering take on capitalism, it's ironic that their stumbling second feature feels throughout like an infomercial for a shtick whose expiration date is rapidly approaching.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The four protagonists aren't about to let something as minor as the complete breakdown of society get in the way of having a good time, and their fun proves infectious.
Quaid and Foster spend far too much time trying to figure out what's going on, but audiences are liable to respond only with a dispirited "Who cares?"
In spite of the fine lead performance, Back is a grey, unedifying slog from grief and hopelessness to parental semi-competence.
Agreeable but highly forgettable.
At best, it angrily demands to be rechristened This Is It! Too often, however, an incredulous This Is It? seems more apt.

Documentaries thrive on candor and intimacy, two qualities the film fatally lacks. Weir has a reputation as a wild child and a loose cannon with little concern for propriety, but he's awfully cautious here about what he reveals about himself.
Valentine's Day explores love in all its myriad forms, from the sickeningly sappy to the cornball to the groaningly precious and obnoxiously cute.
From the moment Gere is introduced waking up to whiskey for breakfast, Brooklyn's Finest segues smoothly and slickly from one cliché to another.
Dunne's messy, unpredictable, yet weirdly vital movie veers from one extreme to another without finding a consistent tone, but Sutherland never strikes a wrong note.
Delivers pretty much exactly what its audience wants and expects: big, dumb, campy fun so deliriously, comically macho, it's remarkable that no one in the cast died of testosterone poisoning.
[A] frenetic jumble of subplots and sleazy characters...
Writer-director Ryan Piers Williams seems to be diligently working through a checklist of returning-warrior-movie clichés.
Simultaneously funnier, darker, and more emotional than its forebear.
With two great, ideally cast actors and such potentially fascinating subject matter, why does Love Ranch feel like a clumsy TV movie?
A Piece Of Work is funny, heartbreaking, and casually profound about the insatiable need for validation and approval that fuels so much stand-up comedy.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film's featherweight tone and self-conscious excess would be a lot more palatable if everyone didn't seem so insufferably pleased with themselves. The film acts as if it's won the race before the starting gun has even been fired.

MacGruber alternates quick bursts of laugh-out-loud funniness with long dry stretches. It isn't exactly good, but for audiences in search of nothing more than a few silly chuckles, it should prove good enough.
Holy Rollers gives a fascinating story the low-rent TV-movie treatment. Ecstasy profiteers and Hasidic Jews both deserve better than Asch's glum slog through their disparate worlds.
Wes Anderson has much to answer for.
With Glenn offscreen for huge sections of the film, Mercy devolves into yet another navel-gazing drama about a glib cad redeemed by the love of a good woman.
It's really two movies, one silly and one serious. Too bad neither is particularly compelling.

Rock acquits himself nicely as the responsible brother and resident straight man, but everyone else in the cast has apparently been advised to mug shamelessly and yell their lines as loudly as possible, especially Tracy Morgan...
The Cartel makes a persuasive argument for vouchers and magnet schools, but its case might be a little stronger if Bowdon didn't appear to be frothing at the mouth with indignation much of the time.

There's something genuine and more than a little sad at the core of Levy's poorly staged, modestly amusing comedy, but it isn't the part that involves flash drives, blackmail, and glowering, gun-toting bad guys.
Machine is engaging enough, but its characters' path to redemption would be more satisfying if it weren't greased with authentically '80s-style casual sexism, gay panic, and frat-comedy clichés.
Though The Eclipse travels a sleepy route to a shrug of anticlimax, it's refreshing to see a film acknowledge that life and love don't end at 50, even in the outsized shadow of a soulmate's death.
Bittersweet and beautifully realized, harsh but humane, Greenberg is a self-consciously small film that nevertheless leaves an indelible mark.

The Runaways were the first major all-girl punk band. In honor of this distinction, they're now the first major all-girl punk band to inspire a bleary, excessive, and altogether mediocre big-screen biography.
Most comedies would be content to mine the comic possibilities of Viagra only once, especially if they're going to devote considerable screen time to the dramatic acting of Carlos Mencia.
Dangerous Man does a serviceable job of mapping out the particulars of his struggle, but the definitive cinematic version of his too-strange-for-fiction story has yet to be made.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Defiance groans under the weight of its deadly earnestness: it's handsomely mounted yet strangely inert.
Perry plugs into the primal power of gospel, blues, soul, and the black church in ways that make Bad far more affecting than it has any right to be.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, frustrating documentary.

It's a huge improvement over the Attenborough film; given the film's non-fiction roots, it seems poetically apt that a documentary take is much more satisfying and engaging than the Hollywood treatment.
What's onscreen is vivid and compelling, but the film only seems to tell part of the story.

Has there ever been a more critic-proof film than Hannah Montana? Montana is targeted with laser precision at an audience barely old enough to read, let alone pay attention to what laptop-toting wretches have to say about its aesthetic shortcomings.

Think of it as a subtle arthouse antidote to the groaning galaxy of baseball movies, a film more concerned with character, mood, and capturing a highly specific cultural milieu than with big games that invariably come down to the very last inning.
Adventureland refreshingly inhabits a world without clear-cut heroes or bad guys, just richly realized characters struggling to get by.

There's something strangely charming about films that are all artifice, explosions, and naked calculation. 12 Rounds is at least honest trash: It never pretends to be anything other than manic schlock.
Malkovich refuses to make his arrogant, prickly has-been remotely likeable, but the movie isn't as uncompromising as his performance, which gets drowned in a sea of schmaltz.
For a sexy comedy that tries and fails to recapture the sensual smarts of vintage screwball fare, Duplicity is regrettably short on sex and comedy.
Rademacher's strange vanity project ends up saying a lot more about his family issues and need to be seen as a swaggering badass than it does about the day-to-day life of soldiers in Iraq.
Tyson can be brutal with himself, but Toback's fawning documentary lets him off easy.

The film's secondhand feel wouldn't be so problematic if it had a sense of urgency, but director Christine Jeffs' ambitions begin and end with transferring Megan Holley's earnest script from the page to the screen.

Chun-Li understandably wasn't screened for critics. It shouldn't be screened for audiences, either. Even Uwe Boll could have done better; at least he makes terrible videogame adaptations with a little personality.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Delirious, top-notch camp for viewers of all faiths and denominations, Megiddo: Omega Code 2 offers so much goofy fun, it's sinful.
Perry's playing-to-the-cheap-seats drag shenanigans hijack a morose street melodrama every 15 minutes and haul it into places even Flavor Flav fears to tread.
Fisher makes for a winning Cinderella, but by its third act, this hokey, old-fashioned vehicle turns back into a pumpkin.
Its premise aches with timely resonance. It's directed with meticulous artistry. So why does it ultimately feel so empty and forgettable?
A great rapper deserves a great biopic, but B.I.G. fans will have to settle for this merely passable one.
A shamelessly sentimental comedy with a few crude gags thrown in arbitrarily.
It's as simplistic, reductive, and heavy-handed as Deep Cover was gloriously ambiguous.
Bride Wars takes the burgeoning Anne Hathaway wedding-movie subgenre from the sublime to the despicable.
March gets the mean-to-funny ratio wrong; it's misanthropic, smutty, and smug, but with a few notable [Craig] Robinson-engineered exceptions, never even remotely chuckle-inducing.
Gentleman is a screamingly quiet film distinguished by a haunting score and terrific lead performances.

Bernal gives his flashy would-be pop star a daft, wide-eyed innocence and it's great to see Bernal and Luna together again, but Cuarón nearly ruins a wonderful comedy by turning it into a much less distinguished drama.
After a relatively dry beginning, the film builds in passion and intensity until attaining a stirring cumulative power.
Louiso's misfiring comedy feels less like a comic feast than a thrown-together assemblage of haphazardly nuked leftovers.
Art & Copy is mightily diverting, for those who don't mind being sold a slick bill of goods.
[A] savagely funny, unexpectedly touching exploration of the human need to idealize and romanticize the dead.

Like a less oppressively hip Juno, Bandslam captures the way young people too smart and pop-culture-savvy for their own good let the music and movies they love define them during adolescence's crucible of humiliation and self-doubt.

As Graham attempts to uncover the truth about his past, the film grows increasingly convoluted, leading to a twist ending that will come as a surprise only to those who've never seen a Shannon Tweed movie.
Dennis Rodman may be a great rebounder, but as a pop-culture icon, he's a one-trick pony.

The film is afflicted with a fatal case of the cutes: It's never an encouraging sign when The Little Prince, that eternal touchstone of precious perma-children, emerges as a major motif for a romantic drama.

The Answer Man combines the worst of both worlds: It offers the ugly digital video, negligible production values, and manufactured grit of a Sundance loser with the pandering formula, sentiment, and romantic-comedy clichés of Hollywood pap.

It soon becomes apparent that Shrink is exactly like virtually all [Spacey's] post-American Beauty vehicles: flashy, phony, nakedly melodramatic, and full of big actorly moments disconnected from real life.
Soul Power works fabulously as both a concert film and a time capsule of a time and place when gods of black masculinity joined forces to make an international statement of togetherness.
Cohen no longer has freshness and novelty on his side, but he's retained the power to shock, offend, provoke, unsettle, and most importantly, entertain a jaded, desensitized public.
An unspeakable nadir in the career of its writer-director-star, My Big Fat Greek Wedding's Nia Vardalos.
Surveillance suggests 'Jennifer Lynchian' should be used for films that aspire to David's moody, idiosyncratic genius and fall woefully short.
Love looks and sounds great, but in depicting N'Dour as a lofty symbol for music's power to bridge worlds and inspire, it sometimes loses sight of the man.
movie_title: Youssou Ndour: I Bring What I Love (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's entertaining and fast-moving enough to make audiences intermittently forget they're consuming cinematic health food.

John Travolta's wildly successful post-comeback crusade to become synonymous with crap continues with The Taking Of Pelham 1 2 3, Tony Scott's bracingly awful remake/desecration of the classic '70s thriller.
Powered by lush cinematography, a moody score, and Owe's subtly majestic lead performance, O'Horten oscillates confidently between the mundane and the rapturously beautiful.
A quasi-sequel to My Big Fat Greek Wedding that shamelessly recycles the sitcom-and-schmaltz formula of Vardalos' breakthrough hit.
Only in the Wayans-brothers universe would "surprisingly not terrible" almost qualify as a ringing endorsement.
A film that flaunts its contempt for plausibility and psychological realism, but damned if Zahn doesn't almost sell the scene and the movie with his naïve, wide-eyed slacker charm.
A very pleasant surprise, Next Day Air is the rare crime comedy that does justice to both sides of the equation.
It's a celebration of brazen nonconformity centered on an insufferable flibbertigibbet who makes the worst case for nonconformity imaginable.

Crudup delivers a bracing, uncompromising performance, but it's unmistakably a solo turn in a romantic comedy that's supposed to be about the blurring of egos and the fusing of two idiosyncratic voices into a single harmonious duet.
Westmoreland and Glatzer adopt a bare-bones documentary-style approach for this sensitive, sharply observed tale.
Radcliffe is the big draw, but he's really a supporting player, just one of the parentless wonders sent to live with a loving couple one glorious, life-changing summer.
Art School Confidential constitutes two-thirds of a worthy follow-up to Ghost World, but it doesn't feel nearly as substantial.
Great satires draw blood. American Dreamz barely nicks the surface.

If [director] Atchison's well-acted, good-intentioned crowd-pleaser can trick even one moviegoer into thinking that knowledge and spelling are somehow cool, then his film will be performing a societal good that offsets its slack reliance on formula.
But even the film's seeming singularity proves deceptive once it becomes apparent that When Do We Eat? is less a Passover movie than a Thanksgiving or Christmas movie dolled up in Jewish drag.

Though deceptively straightforward in its exploration of the causes and effects of domestic abuse, Take My Eyes benefits from the grubby verisimilitude Bollaín brings to his material, which otherwise might have lapsed into movie-of-the-week superficiality
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Once upon a time, Americans snuck off to arthouses largely to sample the forbidden fruit of naked foreign boobs. Some things never change.
Drag queens are people too, Kinky Boots limply, earnestly pleads. Most viewers will respond, 'Yes. And?'

As Hard Candy moves further and further away from its opening scenes' gripping ambiguity, the frightening conviction Page brings to her role becomes the only thing keeping the film from lurching into sleazy, pulpy camp.
Like pretty much everything else bearing Happy Madison's name, The Benchwarmers kind of sucks.
As a director, Garcia is such a sucker for gratuitous crosscutting and glossily elliptical filmmaking that viewers can be forgiven for mistaking Lost City for a 143-minute montage sequence.

Comes coated in several layers of sleaze and grime...

An overly reverent but intermittently compelling homage to an iconoclastic genius...
An action thriller exactly like every other.

A merely good movie.

A singular combination of documentary, essay, narrative, broad comedy, hoax, and cinematic vaudeville.

movie_review_blurb: The film may sound like an instant camp classic, but while it's staggeringly odd, it isn't much fun.

It's a pleasure to catch up with these characters as they approach the complexities and compromises of middle age with all manner of literal and figurative baggage.

Even with the impressive talent assembled in front of and behind the camera, and a healthy budget for a television movie, Body Bags is still little more than an agreeable lark.
In Assault On Precinct 13, hell is an abandoned police station in Los Angeles and the only means of survival is cooperation across racial, class, and legal lines.

The film feels epic in scope, visually at least, but the depth of its deep-focus composition is bitterly at odds with the flimsiness of its characterization and plotting.
If [Anderson] and Wilson love their actors, characters, and ideas too much to reign themselves in, they at least overreach in the service of one of the year's warmest, funniest films.

A strange, wounded beast, filled with wonderful sequences and homemade charm, but also confused and anticlimactic.

Like far too many misfiring prestige films, this attractive mediocrity all but nominates itself for an Academy Award before it's done anything to prove itself remotely award-worthy.
